intro: Diplotaxis galissieri, commonly known as the Galician wallflower, is a flowering plant native to the Iberian Peninsula. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes mustard and cabbages, and is characterized by its small, bright yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or coastal areas, showing a preference for well-drained soils. Its leaves are narrow and linear, often covered in fine hairs, while its stems are erect and can reach up to 30 centimeters in height. Diplotaxis galissieri is a hardy species that thrives in Mediterranean climates and is often found in natural habitats along the coasts of Spain and Portugal.
